III.    Facility Identification

The Rose Packing facility is located at 4900 South Major Avenue in Chicago, Illinois. The facility is a manufacturer of fresh, smoked and processed pork products for the retail and food service industries.  Operations include packing, cooking and processing meats. Rose Packing produces Canadian Style Bacon and a full line of raw and fully cooked pork sausage, ethnic sausage and back ribs.  The facility also makes hams, smoked pork shoulder butts, sectioned and formed processed pork, fresh boneless backs, pork roasts and pork tenderloins.  The NAICS code for the facility is 311612.



The facility uses ammonia for refrigeration, and is regulated under 40 CFR Part 68, the EPA RMP Rule. There is one recirculating closed-loop refrigeration system onsite. The system contains a charge of 49,000 pounds of ammonia, which is above the minimum threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds.

VI.          General Accidental Release Prevention Program

A prevention program is in place to minimize the risk of hazardous chemical releases in accordance with the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and the EPA Risk

Management Program. This prevention program covers those processes that handle ammonia above the threshold quantity for both PSM and RMP rules. The most recent audit of the PSM program was concluded on June 7, 2018, and the next audit will be conducted on, or before June 7, 2021, in compliance with the requirement to conduct PSM audits every three years.  The elements of the PSM / Program 3 prevention program and a brief description are listed below.

?    Employee Participation - Rose Packing has developed a site-specific employee participation plan that ensures employees and their representatives are consulted when conducting and developing process hazard analyses and other information required to be developed under the PSM/RMP regulation.  In addition, the employee participation program ensures employees and their representatives have access to process hazard analyses and all other information required to be developed under PSM/RMP.  Employees at Rose Packing have assisted in developing the initial PHA and the five (5) year PHA revalidation for the ammonia process.  In addition, employees have assisted in the development of other PSM/RMP information such as the development of operating and preventative maintenance procedures.

?    Process Safety Information - Rose Packing has developed a site-specific PSI program that ensures information pertaining to the hazards, technology, and equipment of the process are properly developed and maintained. Process safety information for the ammonia process has been compiled and was last reviewed and updated as of August 30, 2018.

?    Process Hazard Analysis - Rose Packing has developed a site-specific PHA program that ensures a PHA is conducted initially, at a minimum of every five (5) years, and whenever a change is significant enough    to require a change in PSI.  In addition, this program has been established to ensure PHAs are conducted in accordance with OSHA and EPA regulations and to ensure findings and recommendations of P

HAs are properly documented. The last PHA was completed on August 30, 2018.

?    Operating Procedures - Rose Packing has developed a site-specific procedure that ensures operating procedures provide clear instruction for different phases of process operations and ensures they are properly maintained.  The Standard Operating Procedures manual was completed on January 19, 2004. Annually, the operating procedures will be reviewed and certified as accurate.  The most recent review was conducted on May 17, 2019.

?    Training - Rose Packing has developed a site-specific training procedure that ensures employees operating the ammonia process have the knowledge to safely operate the process, are aware of the potential hazards of the process, and understand the causes of process problems.

?    Management of Change - Rose Packing has developed a site-specific management of change procedure that ensures changes (except for replacement in kind) to the ammonia process, such as additions of new equipment or changes in operating, maintenance, or other procedures are documented.  The most recent review MOC was conducted on January 10, 2019.

?    Pre-Startup Review - Rose Packing has developed a site-specific pre-startup safety review procedure that ensures a safety review is performed when modifications to the ammonia process are significant enough to require a change in PSI.  The most recent PSSR was conducted on April 3, 2019.

?    Mechanical Integrity - Rose Packing has developed a site-specific mechanical integrity procedure that ensures written preventative maintenance procedures are developed and maintained, preventative maintenance tests and inspections are properly documented, and employees maintaining the process receive adequate training.  Preventative maintenance procedures have been established within written operating procedures dated January 19, 2004.  The most recent review was conducted on May 17, 2019.  In addition, a preventative maintenance database application has been e

stablished to assist in documenting and tracking preventative maintenance activities.

?    Contractor Qualifications - Rose Packing has developed a site-specific contractor qualification procedure that ensures all contract employers' safety performance and programs are evaluated, a contract employee injury and illness log is maintained, information of potential hazards are communicated between Rose Packing and the contract employer, and required training and information is communicated, such as the provisions of the emergency action plan and control over entrance into process areas.

?    Incident Investigation - Rose Packing has developed a site-specific incident investigation procedure that ensures each incident that either results in a release or could have resulted in a release of anhydrous ammonia is investigated, within 48 hours, by a team of at least one person knowledgeable in the process.  This procedure also makes provisions to ensure a report is prepared at the conclusion of the investigation and findings are promptly addressed. 

?    Compliance Audit - The facility completed an original RMP on June 17, 1999 for the ammonia refrigeration system that held a charge of 34,000 pounds of ammonia. Through modifications made to the ammonia refrigeration system, the amount of ammonia present in the system is now estimated at approximately 49,000 pounds. Compliance audits have been conducted in August 2003, July 2006, July 2009, June 29, 2012, June 5, 2015, and June 7, 2018.  The next compliance audit will be conducted on, or before, June 7, 2021.  Rose Packing, a Division of OSI Industries, LLC has developed a site-specific compliance audit program that ensures compliance audits are conducted at a minimum of every three years to verify that Rose Packing's PSM/RMP practices and procedures are adequate and are being followed.

?    Hot Work Permits - Rose Packing has developed and implemented a best management practice for hot work.



VII.    Five-Year Accident History

Rose P

acking has not had an accidental anhydrous ammonia release, which resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage in the last five years.



VIII.    Emergency Response Program

Rose Packing has an Emergency Action Plan (EAP), updated February 11, 2019, to ensure that in the event of an emergency the facility personnel are aware of the appropriate actions to take and authorities to contact in order to mitigate the effects of a release. Response activities are coordinated with the Central Stickney Fire Department (which coordinates response activities with the Mabis 10 HAZMAT Team). This coordination effort includes providing the fire departments with site diagrams and hazardous material information, meeting with fire department personnel to discuss facility operations/processes, and periodic on-site inspections by fire department personnel.



The facility maintains an EAP on file at the plant. According to the EAP, facility employees are responsible for investigating and assisting the fire department (if necessary) with response to accidental releases of ammonia. The plan includes annual training of all employees on evacuation procedures and emergency notification procedures. The plan also includes annual training for emergency response team members. It identifies the Emergency Action Coordinators, Evacuation Coordinators and alternates. In addition to the facility EAP, the plant is included in a community emergency response plan developed by the Suburban Cook County Central Section Local Emergency Planning Committee. Rose Packing coordinates with the Central Stickney Fire Department (which includes response by the Mabis 10 HAZMAT Team) on emergency response activities. 



The facility has two windsocks present onsite for use in determining wind direction in the event of an ammonia release.



Investigators (responders) receive HAZWOPER t

raining through classroom instruction and drills. HAZWOPER training includes the first responder awareness level, the first responder operations level and hazardous materials technician training.  The facility's Safety Manager also receives incident commander training. Responder HAZWOPER training includes procedures for using and maintaining emergency response equipment as required.



The facility's Onsite Incident Commander or Emergency Response Coordinator (Safety Manager) is responsible for notifying onsite emergency response personnel, emergency response contractors and local, state and federal agencies of releases. The Emergency Response Coordinator (Safety Manager) is responsible for submitting written communication concerning releases to local, state and federal agencies.



The facility's Evacuation Coordinator (Safety Manager) is responsible for coordinating site evacuation in the event of a release that requires evacuation.



The facility's Emergency Action Plan is maintained onsite as part of the Risk Management Program. 



The current Safety Data Sheet (SDS) for anhydrous ammonia is included in Appendix E. 



IX.    Emergency Communications

The telephone numbers of agencies and plant personnel that may be contacted in case of an emergency are included in the facility's Emergency Action Plan.  



X.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Chemical safety is an important part of Rose Packing's operations. Rose Packing conducted an audit of their Process Safety Management Program in June 2018 and is dutifully implementing the recommendations from that audit. The next PSM compliance audit will be conducted on, or before, June 2021 2009.  Continuous improvement in safety is an important goal for Rose Packing. In addition to the facility EAP, the plant is included in a community emergency response plan developed by the LEPC. 



XI.    Management Program

Rose Packing has developed a management system to oversee the implementation of the risk management program ele

ments.  This includes assigning a qualified person (or position) to have overall responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of the risk management program elements.  If any portion of the program is delegated to others, the names or positions of those individuals need to be documented and the lines of authority defined through an organization chart or similar document.  Currently, Michael Mendenhall, Safety Manager, is responsible for overall implementation of the Risk Management Program.
